newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African officers to go and learn from Germany.
newsitem.headline: S.African officers to go and learn from Germany.

text.p: South Africa, trying to forge a united army out of former foes, said on Tuesday it would send officers for training in Germany which recently created a united force out of former East and West German soldiers.

Defence Minister Joe Modise told a news conference he had accepted the proposal from his visiting German counterpart Volker Ruehe, whose aides said 10 officers would go initially for training, ranging from a few weeks to a year.
"We will take full advantage of the offer that has been made," Modise said after talks with Ruehe in Cape Town.
One would go to a U.N. college for peacekeeping, an area where South Africa -- which offered troops for an aborted multinational force for Zaire last year -- is keen to learn.

Modise said South Africa could learn a lot from Germany, particularly its success in fusing a new force out of the old West and East German armies that had icily faced each other across the Iron Curtain before Germany reunited in 1990.

The South African National Defence Force is similarly trying to turn itself into a cohesive national force made up of members of the old apartheid army and their former enemies from the African National Congress's armed wing.

Modise said South Africa would wait for a full defence review, due to be completed in April, before deciding on a possible purchase of corvettes -- equivalent to European light frigates -- for its navy.
Ruehe, asked about Germany's reported interest in bidding to sell the ships to Pretoria's navy, said only that Bonn had an interest in "technical cooperation" with South Africa's defence ministry.
He is on a tour of Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.
